Definition: You are given four sentences of a story written in natural language. Your job is to select an incorrect end sentence from (A) and (B) such that the story does not sound complete and coherent.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. Also, he was previously in gang, so, this incident cannot make him to join a gang. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious and she should not cancel going to her friend's party. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. So, A is incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. However, B is correct answer, not incorrect.

Instances.input:
Sentence1: Cindy got out of bed. Sentence2: But she couldn't find her slippers. Sentence3: Instead of making breakfast, spent all day looking for them. Sentence4: She gave up and ordered another pair. 
 (A) She also ordered an iPhone. (B) Luckily, the new ones were more comfortable than the old ones.

Sentence1: Jane was paranoid and valued her privacy. Sentence2: She went out to the mall to look for a privacy filter. Sentence3: At the mobile shop, she found one that would fit her phone. Sentence4: She had them install the privacy filter. 
 (A) She shared her phone number with all her friends. (B) That helped her feel more relaxed.

Sentence1: Westin was getting married! Sentence2: He wanted his wedding to go perfectly. Sentence3: Everything went well until the evening. Sentence4: Someone got very intoxicated and fell into the cake! 
 (A) Westin cut a perfect slice from the cake. (B) Weston and his wife kicked out the intoxicated person.

Sentence1: Ana was a hardworking mom. Sentence2: One day she booked herself an afternoon at a spa. Sentence3: She had her whole body massaged. Sentence4: She even had hydrotherapy sessions. 
 (A) Someday, she told herself, she would get a full-body massage. (B) She felt magnificently relaxed and contented afterwards.

Sentence1: My dog waited for me by the house front door. Sentence2: We walked to the park for playtime and exercise. Sentence3: The dog and I walked around the block before returning home. Sentence4: When we walked through the front door, she took a big drink of water. 
 (A) Then she lay down and took a nap. (B) She was jumping up and down begging for a walk.

Sentence1: Joe stretched as he rolled over in bed. Sentence2: His clock showed it was 10 am. Sentence3: He jumped out of bed, panicked. Sentence4: His alarm hadn't gone off. 
 (A) Joe was late for work. (B) Joe went back to sleep.

Sentence1: Dana's mother came to visit for a week. Sentence2: Dana's husband Glenn thinks her mother is trying to poison him. Sentence3: During breakfast Glenn stomach starts to cramp. Sentence4: Glen becomes outraged. 
 (A) However, turns out to just be gas. (B) However, Glen hugs his mother-in-law.

Sentence1: David and Sarah were friends during childhood. Sentence2: When they went to college, each moved to a different town. Sentence3: Sarah received an unexpected call from David on Friday. Sentence4: They had dinner and talked about their lives. 
 (A) Sarah was glad they were able to catch up. (B) Sarah and david went to go get dinner right after that.
